title: WKTV
text:
WKTV, <a href="virtual%20channel">virtual channel</a> 2 (<a href="ultra%20high%20frequency">UHF</a> <a href="Digital%20terrestrial%20television">digital</a> channel 29), is an <a href="NBC">NBC</a>/<a href="CBS">CBS</a>/<a href="The%20CW%20Plus">CW+</a>-<a href="network%20affiliate">affiliated</a> <a href="television%20station">television station</a> <a href="city%20of%20license">licensed</a> to <a href="Utica%2C%20New%20York">Utica, New York</a>, United States and serving <a href="Central%20New%20York">Central</a> <a href="Upstate%20New%20York">Upstate New York</a>'s <a href="Mohawk%20Valley">Mohawk Valley</a>. The station is owned by <a href="Heartland%20Media">Heartland Media</a>. WKTV's studios are located on <a href="Smith%20Hill%20%28Oneida%20County%2C%20New%20York%29">Smith Hill Road</a> in <a href="Deerfield%2C%20New%20York">Deerfield</a> (with a Utica <a href="United%20States%20Postal%20Service">postal</a> address), and its transmitter is located in the Eatonville section of <a href="Fairfield%2C%20New%20York">Fairfield</a>. On <a href="cable%20television">cable</a>, WKTV is available on <a href="Spectrum%20%28cable%20service%29">Charter Spectrum</a> channel 4 in both <a href="standard-definition%20television">standard</a> and high definition.
History.
The station launched on December 1, 1949, as Utica's first television station, operating on <a href="Very%20high%20frequency">Very high frequency</a> (VHF) channel 13. It was the 93rd television station in the United States to sign on. This made Utica one of the smallest cities in the nation with a television station. It was owned by Copper City Broadcasting Corporation, controlled by Myron Kallet, along with <a href="WKAL">WKAL</a> (1450 AM). As the only station in its area, it was affiliated with all four major networks at the time: NBC, <a href="DuMont%20Television%20Network">DuMont</a>, <a href="American%20Broadcasting%20Company">ABC</a>, and CBS, with NBC being its primary affiliation. It lost DuMont in 1956 following the network's closure, and lost CBS soon afterward following a dispute with the network; after that, <a href="WTVH">WHEN-TV/WTVH</a> in <a href="Syracuse%2C%20New%20York">Syracuse</a> served as the default CBS affiliate for the Utica area until 2015.
The station was a major beneficiary of a quirk in the <a href="Federal%20Communications%20Commission">Federal Communications Commission</a> (FCC)'s plan for allocating stations. In the early days of broadcast television, there were twelve VHF channels available and 69 UHF channels (later reduced to 55 in 1983). The VHF bands were more desirable because they carried longer distances. Since there were only twelve VHF channels available, there were limitations as to how closely the stations could be spaced.
After the FCC's Sixth Report and Order ended the license freeze and opened the UHF band in 1952, it devised a plan for allocating VHF licenses. Under this plan, almost all of the country would be able to receive two commercial VHF channels plus one noncommercial channel. Most of the rest of the country ("1/2") would be able to receive a third VHF channel. Other areas would be designated as "UHF islands" since they were too close to larger cities for VHF service. The "2" networks became CBS and NBC, "+1" represented non-commercial educational stations, and "1/2" became ABC (which was the weakest network usually winding up with the UHF allocation where no VHF was available).
However, Utica was sandwiched between <a href="Albany%2C%20New%20York">Albany, New York</a> (channels <a href="WRGB">4 (later 6)</a> and <a href="WTEN">10</a>, later joined by <a href="WNYT%20%28TV%29">13</a>) to the east, Syracuse (channels <a href="WSTM-TV">3</a>, <a href="WTVH">5</a>, and <a href="WSYR-TV">9</a>) to the west, <a href="Binghamton">Binghamton</a> (channel <a href="WBNG">12</a>) to the south, and <a href="Watertown%2C%20New%20York">Watertown</a> (channel <a href="WWNY">7</a>) and <a href="Plattsburgh">Plattsburgh</a> (channels <a href="WCAX-TV">3</a> and <a href="WPTZ">5</a>) to the north. This resulted in the Utica market having only "one" VHF license; WKTV was fortunate enough to gain that license, and as a result remained the only television station based in Utica for its first 21 years of existence. Although there were no allocations of channels 2, 8, and 11 in the immediate area, channel <a href="WGRZ">2</a> was occupied in <a href="Buffalo%2C%20New%20York">Buffalo</a>, channel <a href="WPIX">11</a> was occupied in <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a>, and channel 8 was occupied in <a href="WTNH">New Haven</a> and later <a href="WROC-TV">Rochester</a>, which were all too close to Utica to reallocate at the time.
In 1951, a young local <a href="Radio%20broadcasting">radio</a> announcer named <a href="Dick%20Clark">Dick Clark</a> joined the staff at WKTV. He quickly gathered a loyal following. Clark's father was the manager of Utica radio station WRUN (1150 AM, later to become <a href="WUTI">WUTI</a> and shut down in 2013; and 104.3 FM, now <a href="WFRG-FM">WFRG-FM</a>), and his son wanted to avoid the name recognition factor. To avoid confusion, the younger Clark became known on-air as "Dick Clay". Eventually, Clark would anchor the weeknight newscasts on WKTV (replacing <a href="Robert%20Earle">Robert Earle</a>, who would later host the "<a href="College%20Bowl">GE College Bowl</a>"). In 1952, Clark departed WKTV for <a href="WFIL">WFIL AM</a>-<a href="WIOQ">FM</a>-<a href="WPVI-TV">TV</a> in <a href="Philadelphia">Philadelphia</a>.
In 1958, Kallet sold WKTV and WKAL to a group led by Paul Harron and Gordon Gray, who had previously owned <a href="WNTP">WIBG AM</a>-<a href="WIP-FM">FM</a> in Philadelphia and <a href="WVUE%20%28Wilmington%2C%20Delaware%29">WPFH</a> in <a href="Wilmington%2C%20Delaware">Wilmington, Delaware</a>. Soon afterward, on January 1, 1959, WKTV moved to VHF channel 2 in a dial realignment, which allowed WTRI (channel 35) in Albany to move to channel 13 (where it became WAST, now WNYT), and (along with the earlier move of a channel 13 allocation in <a href="Hamilton%2C%20Ontario">Hamilton, Ontario</a> to channel 11, becoming <a href="CHCH-DT">CHCH-TV</a>) led to a channel 13 allocation being assigned to Rochester (which signed on in 1962 as WOKR and is now <a href="WHAM-TV">WHAM-TV</a>). With the switch, WKTV upgraded its signal and began to cover a fairly wide area stretching from as far south as the <a href="Catskill%20Mountains">Catskill Mountains</a>, as far east as <a href="The%20Berkshires">The Berkshires</a> in <a href="Western%20Massachusetts">Western Massachusetts</a> and into <a href="Southern%20Ontario">Southern Ontario</a>, Canada. The Harron/Gray group, Mid-New York Broadcasting, sold WKAL in 1961, but retained WKTV, and in subsequent years acquired several additional stations, including <a href="KAUZ-TV">KAUZ-TV</a> in <a href="Wichita%20Falls%2C%20Texas">Wichita Falls, Texas</a>, and <a href="WHOM">WMTW-FM</a>-<a href="WMTW%20%28TV%29">TV</a> on <a href="Mount%20Washington%20%28New%20Hampshire%29">Mount Washington, New Hampshire</a>. Harron also operated a chain of cable systems in the <a href="Northeastern%20United%20States%20%28U.S.%20Census%20Bureau%29">Northeastern United States</a>, including a system in Utica, Central New York Cable TV (Later, Harron Cable TV) built in 1963. The company eventually became known as Harron Communications Corporation.
WKTV enjoyed a monopoly in the Utica television market until February 28, 1970, when <a href="WUTR">WUTR</a> signed on as an ABC affiliate. WKTV then became affiliated solely with NBC, and is now one of the network's longest-serving affiliates. In the mid-1980s, the FCC ruled on cross-ownership of broadcast, cable and print media in the same market. The FCC <a href="grandfather%20clause">grandfathered</a> Harron. A few years later Harron acquired a cable system in nearby <a href="Canajoharie%2C%20New%20York">Canajoharie, New York</a>, then owned by a local appliance dealer. The Canajoharie plant extended well within a contour of WKTV's <a href="Middleville%2C%20New%20York">Middleville</a> transmitter site. The FCC revoked Harron's grandfather status and required divestiture of either its cable or television assets in the region. In 1992, Harron sold controlling interest in WKTV to Smith Broadcasting (the cable system was later sold to <a href="Adelphia%20Communications%20Corporation">Adelphia</a> and is now part of <a href="Charter%20Communications">Charter Communications</a>). In 2004, Boston Ventures, acquired the Smith Broadcasting stations, and formed <a href="Smith%20Media">Smith Media, LLC</a>, after founder Bob Smith died in 2003.
WKTV has been broadcasting its digital signal on UHF channel 29 since May 2006 and in high definition starting with the <a href="2008%20Summer%20Olympics">2008 Summer Olympics</a>. The station signed off its analog signal on <a href="2009%20in%20American%20television">February 18, 2009</a>, and began broadcasting <a href="Digital%20television%20transition%20in%20the%20United%20States">exclusively in digital</a>. This left some viewers without a reachable signal and others looking for an outdoor UHF antenna. To continue serving those areas, WKTV began simulcasting its weekday newscasts at noon and 5:00 p.m. on WUTQ (1550 AM, now <a href="WUSP%20%28AM%29">WUSP</a>) and WADR (1480 AM, now <a href="WRCK%20%28AM%29">WRCK</a>). In May 2011, the radio stations began simulcasting the second hour of WKTV's weekday morning show. On March 16, 2012, <a href="WUTQ-FM">WUTQ-FM</a> (100.7 FM), then simulcasting WUTQ/WRCK, began simulcasting the newscasts. WUTQ/WRCK broke from the simulcast later that year when WUTQ-FM owner Ken Roser sold the stations to Good Guys Broadcasting Corporation. WUTQ-FM continues to simulcast WKTV's 5:00 p.m. newscast and its weekday morning show; however, it now simulcasts the first hour due to an expansion of its popular morning talk show "Talk Of The Town".
Due to an ongoing retransmission dispute, Time Warner Cable replaced WKTV with fellow NBC affiliate <a href="WBRE-TV">WBRE-TV</a> from <a href="Wilkes-Barre%2C%20Pennsylvania">Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania</a>, on December 16, 2010. WKTV-DT2 was also dropped and eventually replaced by <a href="HBO%20Family">HBO Family</a>. On the same date, rival WUTR began to be seen in the <a href="Burlington%2C%20Vermont">Burlington, Vermont</a>–<a href="Plattsburgh%20%28city%29%2C%20New%20York">Plattsburgh, New York</a>, market on Time Warner Cable after sister station <a href="WVNY">WVNY</a> was dropped for the same reason. <a href="Nexstar%20Media%20Group">Nexstar Broadcasting Group</a>, owner of WBRE, and <a href="Mission%20Broadcasting">Mission Broadcasting</a> (a broadcaster whose stations are operated by Nexstar), owner of WUTR, opposed the use of their stations as replacement programming and requested the Time Warner Cable <a href="Franchising">franchise</a> for the affected regions be revoked. WKTV and Time Warner reached an agreement, the terms of which both sides refused to reveal, on January 8, 2011, allowing WKTV and the CW subchannel to return to the cable system the next day. (Ironically, WVNY would later be sold to Mission Broadcasting, making it a sister station to WUTR.))
On October 1, 2013, Smith Media reached a deal to sell WKTV to Heartland Media, a newly-formed company owned by former <a href="Gray%20Television">Gray Television</a> executive Bob Prather. The sale was completed on March 20, 2014. WKTV launched a third digital subchannel eight months later on November 10, carrying programming from <a href="MeTV">MeTV</a>.
Subchannels.
WKTV-DT2.
WKTV-DT2 is the <a href="CBS">CBS</a>-affiliated second <a href="digital%20subchannel">digital subchannel</a> of WKTV, broadcasting in 720p high definition on UHF channel 29.2 (or virtual channel 2.2 via <a href="Program%20and%20System%20Information%20Protocol">PSIP</a>). The subchannel can also be seen on Spectrum channel 5.
History.
WKTV-DT2 signed on in September 1998 alongside the creation of <a href="The%20WB%20100%2B%20Station%20Group">The WB 100+</a>. WKTV partnered with the group to launch a <a href="cable%20television">cable</a>-only <a href="The%20WB">WB</a> affiliate. This new service replaced <a href="superstation">superstation</a> WPIX from New York City on Harron Cable (then Adelphia, later Time Warner, now Spectrum) systems in the Mohawk Valley (which had been carried dating back to its days as an independent station) and it used the "WBU" (standing for The WB Utica) call sign in a fictional manner. 
In January 2006, The WB and <a href="UPN">UPN</a> announced that they would merge and form <a href="The%20CW">The CW Television Network</a>, from which affiliates were to be drawn from existing WB and UPN affiliates. "WBU" was chosen to become the CW affiliate for Utica, while UPN affiliate <a href="WPNY-LD">WPNY-LP</a> associated itself with <a href="MyNetworkTV">MyNetworkTV</a> (a network started by <a href="Fox%20Broadcasting%20Company">Fox</a>, whose Utica affiliate <a href="WFXV">WFXV</a> was a sister station to WPNY-LP) for UPN or WB affiliates not chosen by The CW. Responding to the selection, WKTV launched a new second digital subchannel to simulcast "WBU" and offer off-air access to CW programming, which begun along with the CW on September 18. The station then began using the WKTV-DT2 calls in an official manner. Originally, this subchannel was known on-air as Central New York's CW but was eventually re-branded to Central New York's CW 11 (and more recently The CW 11) to reflect its location on Time Warner Cable systems. Ultimately, the new subchannel replaced "WBU" altogether.
On October 26, 2015, WKTV announced that it would change WKTV-DT2's affiliation from The CW to CBS on November 22 (rebranding the subchannel as CBS Utica). The new affiliation marks the first time CBS has had an affiliate in Utica since the end of WKTV's secondary affiliation with the network in the mid-1950s, as well as the first time CBS has ever had a full-time affiliate in Utica. (Prior to this, WTVH in Syracuse and <a href="WBNG-TV">WBNG</a> in <a href="Binghamton%2C%20New%20York">Binghamton</a> served as the default CBS affiliates via cable for the Utica market; WTVH was able to be picked up over-the-air in portions of the Utica market before it shut down its analog signal.) Within a month of the subchannel's launch, WKTV-DT2 had replaced WTVH on Time Warner Cable channel 5 in Utica proper, while DirecTV later added WKTV-DT2 to its local packages, as did Dish Network shortly after the new year. On July 1, 2016, WKTV-DT2 was re-launched in the rest of the Utica DMA when the station replaced WTVH in <a href="Herkimer%20County%2C%20New%20York">Herkimer County</a> and WBNG in <a href="Otsego%20County%2C%20New%20York">Otsego County</a>. However, as a result of viewer complaints in Otsego County, WBNG was restored to Time Warner Cable systems in that area (alongside WKTV-DT2) on January 25, 2017.
In May 2016, WKTV-DT2 upgraded their over-the-air digital signal into 720p high definition; thus offering a locally operated in-market over-the-air HD feed for CBS for the first time in the Utica–Rome market.
WKTV-DT3.
WKTV-DT3 is the CW+-affiliated third digital subchannel of WKTV, broadcasting in 720p high definition on UHF channel 29.6 (or virtual channel 2.3 via PSIP). The subchannel is branded as Central New York's CW 11 in reference to its channel position on Spectrum cable systems in the area.
History.
The station signed on November 10, 2014, as an affiliate of MeTV. As recommended by <a href="Weigel%20Broadcasting">Weigel Broadcasting</a>, MeTV's owners, WKTV-DT3 cleared the entire MeTV schedule. After much deliberation between WKTV and Time Warner Cable, WKTV-DT3 was added to Time Warner Cable's Utica line-up in the summer of 2015 on channel 1245.
On October 26, 2015, concurrent with WKTV's announcement that WKTV-DT2 would be joining CBS, it was also announced that WKTV-DT3 would switch its affiliation from MeTV to The CW (WKTV-DT2's former affiliation), while MeTV programs would be moved to a newly created fourth subchannel. Like WKTV-DT2's switch to CBS, both changes also took effect on November 22. WKTV-DT3 subsequently inherited WKTV-DT2's cable channel position, as well as its programming from The CW Plus, while the new fourth subchannel immediately took over WKTV-DT3's former cable channel position.
In May 2016, WKTV-DT3 upgraded its over-the-air digital signal into 720p high definition; thus offering over-the-air access to The CW's HD feed for the first time in the Utica–Rome market.

Programming.
Main channel.
In addition to the NBC network schedule, <a href="Broadcast%20syndication">syndicated programming</a> on WKTV includes "<a href="Wheel%20of%20Fortune%20%28American%20game%20show%29">Wheel of Fortune</a>", "<a href="Jeopardy%21">Jeopardy!</a>", "<a href="Dr.%20Phil%20%28talk%20show%29">Dr. Phil</a>" and "<a href="Judge%20Judy">Judge Judy</a>".
WKTV-DT2.
In addition to the CBS network schedule, syndicated programming on WKTV's DT2 channel include "<a href="The%20Drew%20Barrymore%20Show">The Drew Barrymore Show</a>", "<a href="Right%20This%20Minute">Right This Minute</a>" and "<a href="Daily%20Mail%20TV">Daily Mail TV</a>".
WKTV-DT3.
Outside of CW network programming, WKTV's DT3 channel receives its programs from <a href="The%20CW%20Plus">The CW Plus</a>, except for locally produced newscasts on weekdays.
News operation.
Main channel.
The station has been a <a href="Nielsen%20ratings">ratings</a> stronghold in the Mohawk Valley for its entire history. For the most part, this is because the station had no local competition before WUTR's 1970 sign on; in addition, WUTR aired no local newscasts from August 2003 through September 2011, again leaving WKTV as the lone news operation in the market.
In September 2001, WKTV entered into a news share agreement with Fox affiliate WFXV (then owned by Quorum Broadcasting), leading to a 10:00 p.m. newscast on that station. Known as "NewsChannel 2 on Fox", the show aired every night for a half-hour and was virtually identical to WKTV's regular newscasts. The broadcast generally originated live from WKTV's studios; however, there were frequently technical problems beaming the show to WFXV's facility on Greenfield Road in Rome through <a href="microwave%20relay">microwave relay</a>. Sometimes, WKTV personnel had to record the newscast in advance and physically deliver the videotape to WFXV; the stations' studios are next to each other on top of Smith Hill in Deerfield, New York.
When the outsourcing contract ended on August 31, 2004, WFXV decided not to renew it (by this point, WFXV was owned by Nexstar Broadcasting Group and operated Mission Broadcasting's WUTR through a joint sales agreement). The next day, the 10:00 p.m. newscast moved to cable-exclusive "WBU", with the weekend edition dropped; the newscast continued on the station, which became WKTV-DT2 in 2006, until WKTV-DT2 switched affiliations to CBS on November 22, 2015. At that point, the newscast moved to WKTV-DT3, where it continues to air to this day.
Newscasts on WKTV officially upgraded to true high definition on January 29, 2015, making WKTV the third station in the Utica area (behind WUTR and WFXV) to switch. Its HD conversion was a two-step process, beginning with the construction of a new set, which debuted on August 4, 2014, and continuing with the replacement of its news and engineering equipment with HD-ready versions.
During <a href="Weather%20forecasting">weather forecast</a> segments, WKTV features live <a href="National%20Oceanic%20and%20Atmospheric%20Administration">National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration</a> (NOAA) <a href="National%20Weather%20Service">National Weather Service</a> <a href="Weather%20radar">Doppler weather radar</a> data from several regional sites. On-air, this system is known as "StormTracker 2 Live Doppler".
WKTV-DT2.
WKTV-DT2 currently simulcasts the 6:00 a.m. half-hour of its parent station's morning newscast, the first half-hour of its noon newscast, and its 11:00 p.m. newscast; the second half-hour of the noon newscast only airs on WKTV to allow WKTV-DT2 to air "<a href="The%20Young%20and%20the%20Restless">The Young and the Restless</a>" in CBS's recommended 12:30 p.m. time slot. Although plans for WKTV to produce exclusive newscasts for the subchannel using CBS resources have yet to be realized, WKTV also produces periodic specials that air on the subchannel.
WKTV-DT3.
When WKTV-DT3 first signed on, it did not air any newscasts in favor of MeTV programming. However, on November 23, 2015, WKTV-DT3 began airing the 10:00 p.m. newscast that had previously aired on WKTV-DT2 as a CW affiliate. On January 25, 2016, WKTV-DT3 also added a 7:00 a.m. newscast, making it the first station in the Utica market to carry local news at that time. Both newscasts air every weekday for a half-hour and are virtually identical to WKTV's regular newscasts.
